text: <@U01AD80KMLK> That abstract looks interesting... the preprint is on my ebook reader for the weekend. The "Abstract Wikipedia" project looks a bit like an open version of Stephen Wolfram's vision of a computational encyclopedia. And even though the development processes of the two projects are at the opposite ends of the spectrum, I think Wikipedia could learn a lot from his work.

elements.text: That abstract looks interesting... the preprint is on my ebook reader for the weekend. The "Abstract Wikipedia" project looks a bit like an open version of Stephen Wolfram's vision of a computational encyclopedia. And even though the development processes of the two projects are at the opposite ends of the spectrum, I think Wikipedia could learn a lot from his work.

text: <@UJBAJNFLK> yes, I am well aware of his work (although I have to admit, I skimmed over most of NKS). We don't plan to be founded in a single unifying principle based on cell automata (which might or might not be a differentiator, I really don't know - I can see how this could allow Alpha to have a more interesting evolution path), and we will be entirely in the open (which I think is a qualitative difference, as it allows for very different patterns). I am deeply impressed by Stephen's work, and try to follow it.

elements.text: yes, I am well aware of his work (although I have to admit, I skimmed over most of NKS). We don't plan to be founded in a single unifying principle based on cell automata (which might or might not be a differentiator, I really don't know - I can see how this could allow Alpha to have a more interesting evolution path), and we will be entirely in the open (which I think is a qualitative difference, as it allows for very different patterns). I am deeply impressed by Stephen's work, and try to follow it.

text: NKS and Wolfram's recent fundamental physics projects are a different story. I was thinking of his work on the Wolfram Language, including Wolfram Alpha but also Mathematica. There's a lot of computationally accessible knowledge about the world in those systems.

elements.text: NKS and Wolfram's recent fundamental physics projects are a different story. I was thinking of his work on the Wolfram Language, including Wolfram Alpha but also Mathematica. There's a lot of computationally accessible knowledge about the world in those systems.

text: Yes, in the sense of making more knowledge accessible through computation, yes, that's very much aligned with the goals of Alpha and Mathematica.

elements.text: Yes, in the sense of making more knowledge accessible through computation, yes, that's very much aligned with the goals of Alpha and Mathematica.
